message: I would love a Windows desktop app that would sync to dropbox and share with PlainText. I did find one but it created cryptic named txt files.
My go to place to send notes for the past several years has been Google Notebook.  I'm glad they didn't totally removie it but why did they have to disable browser addons?
I have a first gen. iPod Touch so the new notes sync in the google exchange server sync isn't available to me.
I have LastPass and will continue to use it for secure notes but it isn't handy for quick casual notes as in "I need to remember this bit of information".
Google wants people to move to Google Docs but it seems overkill for just remembering a single number and it doesn't seem to sync to iOS, at least 3.x
Evernote for detailed note taking.  But I also use Catch and Springpad for other uses.

I found PlainText, which is a free iOS notes app which syncs to dropbox as plain text files named "Title.txt". I have been using a text editor to create notes in the folder and they get sent to PlainText when I open it. I like it that notes stay there so they can be accessed easily offline. I use the Evernote app but it complains when I'm offline and I'm never sure what's kept in the app for offline access (in the free version.

I use Evernote on phone and on computers. Have used OneNote (Microsoft) since 2003 however I am switching everything to Evernote due to the synchronization ability between devices. You can store pictures and sounds as well as just notes and then export out Word if you need that.
I just installed Simplenote.  It's free, has a Windows and iPhone client and supports tags for sorting.
Pieces for iPhone by @alexmills
i also use scrivener as a writing tool, so my writing notes are in there
evernote is great for general note-taking
@estesworld Thanks for suggesting Springpad.  Anyone want to help me test the social aspect of it?  I'm "telliott at gmail dot com"
I'm using SimpleNote, a web service, VERY crisp, clean and unencumbered, along with Resphonotes, a freeware desktop app (windows) that syncs with SimpleNote. Easy peasy, lemon squeezy. All FREE.

I use OneNote on my laptop and use tools like FreeFileSync to sync the files with my fileserver when I'm home.  I ditched using EverNote last year because it is pain in the butt not able to embedded images or clips within my notes or editorials.  EverNote still has that beta feel to it.
@telliott thanks for recommending PlainText it's now my main note taking app I love it!
I use either ubernote.com or onenote. One note can sync using a live account, so its synched between all of computer anyway. Ubernote is good since you don't need any interface at all.
Evernote has so many features and u recommend you pay the pay features are amazing
Notes from apple!!
Wow, NO one has mentioned PlainText yet!
@JonMwords i counted 2 people has mentioned it. 3 including yours.
me, evernote for, well, note taking. stickies widget on OSX, and Notes on iOS
Oh. I was having weird new Convore code display issues. Or maybe just inattention and impatience.
I use evernote with my droid.  I have a paid account.  I am their slave
@unwrangle how do you sync across or do you find that you don't need that

I use simplenote (web). have an app for it on my phone and iPad. and use nvALT to sync with it on my Mac. it's plain text only but that restriction is good for me. anything else I want to save goes into google docs.

@verbal I kinda don't... like for me, notes are generally taken at work, for work stuff, between pen - paper and basecamp, it's plenty. the stickies widget contains mostly just code / numbers; API keys for some web services that I'm playing around, or some reference number that i write down when I'm on the phone with the bank. nevertheless, evernote is a great product. I just don't have many use of it...
@telliott I use Plaintext a lot. With the laptop, I just use Notepad++ to open/create/save text documents, and save them in Docs/Dropbox/Plaintext folder. Is that what you meant?

I love evernote, great away to organize notes/documents into notebooks, but still be able to tag and add links.  I've just recently began heavy usage of the chrome plugin to clip images/pages and that has increased my productivity to entirely new level.
A good android alternative to plain text is Epistle. I just started using it and love it thus far.
Gmail. I just send myself an email. If I'm offline, I save as a draft.

I love Delicious. It's my bookmark of choice. Yahoo's biggest problem appears to me to be it lack of cutting edge anything. They have the eye of about 70 million people per month on their home page, yet can't seem to excite any of these people. Poor management is at the heart of Yahoo's decline and if not changed will be it's ultimate down fall.
I use Evernote.  I have the app on my laptop, iPhone, and iPad.
i really really want a note taking app that will do math symbols. like big sigma.

Thanks for all your suggestions.  It seems there are lots of ways to sync notes.  I think I've settled with Springboard for it's simplicity and it's social features.  Also the Chrome app makes it really quick to add a note, like Evernote.  I just don't use Evernote enough to justify a paid account.  I will remind everyone again about Lastpass!  I will always keep my secure notes there but because ot it's high level of security and my long, hard to enter master password, it's not as convenient as Springboard for quick notes.
Evernote for everything I want to remember. I also use element to sync note with Dropbox.
I love WriteRoom because it makes my screen look like an old, VT100 terminal with green text and a black screen. Bring back 1991 in a hard way!
I use springpad which I find great.
+1 for Evernote and notational velocity (nvALT)
+1 for any #SimpleNote client !
Emacs w/ org-mode
I think notes aren't very effective without reminders. I find myself using Due (in the iOS App Store) a great deal.
@barce I agree
I've tried lots and settled on Evernote but only since the last iPhone update. Big improvement over the first few iOS versions.
I like Workflowy because it is so simple, yet so capable.
simplenote
just checked out workflowy and its great for outlining
will have to wait for a mobile version though which is work in progress
Evernote by far...
and in some linux distribution.. Tomboy?
Absolutely Evernote. I use the voicenote feature a lot for quick reminders. $5/month for Premium is practically giving it away.
Notational Velocity without doubt

Something I absolutely love for it's simplicity, portability and sharing abilities is write.fm. Add a page name, take a note and share the URL with someone if you wish to share. Else, go to any other device and fire up the URL to see your note again. No login, no passwords. Fascinatingly simple.
ShoveBox is pretty nice, especially if/when you use it on both an iOS device and a Mac. Worth the price on both platforms.
WorkFlowy! (Disclosure: I make Workflowy)

Workflowy.  Its simple, usable interface blows everything else out of the water.  Right now, you can only input text and it doesn't have a quick add extension like many others do, but it more than makes up for that failing with its interface.
Quick note for google chrome, always one tab away, great for individual notes. Not for collaboration.
I made a publicly editable Workflowy list to discuss what the best note app is.  Help decide the winner!  http://workflowy.com/shared/1049f76c-447b-d205-1aae-47d7763c6722/
